docs.lead_paragraph: It took only a few weeks for Merck & Company, the nation's biggest drug maker, to note the damage after the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York told its 850,000 members that it would no longer pay for most of Merck's highly regarded but often expensive products. Several of Merck's banner drugs abruptly lost customers. Take just one example. Sales of Vasotec, a heart and blood pressure treatment, plummeted in early 1994, going from 60 percent of the prescriptions for HIP members using this class of drug to fewer than 5 percent for those who could not use a substitute, according to executives of the big health maintenance organization.

headline.main: The New Drug-Price Squeeze;H.M.O.'s Are Fighting Back in the Battle Over Costs

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HEALTH INSURANCE PLAN OF GREATER NEW YORK

docs.lead_paragraph: EXTREME weight loss, known as wasting, long recognized and dreaded as a hallmark of cancer, has puzzled researchers for decades. Patients literally waste away, acquiring an almost skeletal look. Some actually die from the wasting rather than the cancer, researchers say. Even though wasting is considered a serious illness in and of itself, the mechanism has eluded scientists. British researchers, however, say they have identified a central biochemical player in the process of wasting, a substance they say is made by tumor cells that appears to cause the weight loss. It is a highly unusual molecule -- a small protein attached to a large sugar, classified as a proteoglycan -- and it is unlike any substance ever linked to wasting in the past. The researchers reported their findings on Feb. 22 in the journal Nature.

headline.main: Unusual Molecule Could Be Key To Cancer Patient's Weight Loss

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER school, the smokers head to the curb to light up. It's the same curb smokers at Elizabeth High School have used forever -- across the street from the Dunn Sports Center, in front of the corner grocery. "A habit, I guess," said one of the smokers, dragging long and hard on a Camel. We'll call him Joe. Anything more, he said, could get him in trouble. His mother would throw a fit if she found out he was smoking (again). The first time she caught him, he forfeited his $15 allowance for two weeks. The next time, the penalty would be harsher. "She'd tell my father," Joe said.

headline.main: Our Towns;Calls for Bans As Students Keep Puffing
